authors.name: Sebastian Krakowski
authors.affiliation: Professor of Strategy, Stockholm School of Economics
authors.expertise: Artificial intelligence in competitive strategy, human-machine collaboration

authors.name: Johannes Luger
authors.affiliation: Professor of Strategic Management, University of St. Gallen
authors.expertise: Resource-based view, strategic capabilities, and technology adoption

authors.name: Sebastian Raisch
authors.affiliation: Professor of Strategy, University of Geneva

basic_information.title: Artificial Intelligence and the Changing Sources of Competitive Advantage

journal.name: Strategic Management Journal
journal.impact: Premier journal for research on strategic management and technological advancements

abstract.summary: This study applies the resource-based view to investigate the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on competitive advantage and performance. Using chess as a controlled context, it highlights how AI-driven substitution and complementation dynamics affect human-machine collaboration and performance differentiation, reshaping traditional strategic capabilities.

core_theories.name: Resource-Based View (RBV)
core_theories.description: AI reshapes competitive capabilities by substituting traditional human skills while enabling new human-machine resource bundles.

key_insights: Traditional cognitive capabilities lose value with AI adoption.
AI creates new competitive capabilities through complementation with human adaptability and strategic insights.

hypotheses.H1: AI adoption substitutes traditional human cognitive capabilities, reducing their strategic value.
hypotheses.rationale: AI's superior computational power and consistency outperform human decision-making in repetitive tasks.

hypotheses.H2: AI complements human strategic thinking, enabling new competitive advantages.
hypotheses.rationale: Human creativity and adaptability combine with AI's tactical precision to enhance performance.

hypotheses.H3: Substitution and complementation dynamics are interrelated and collectively reshape competitive advantage.
hypotheses.rationale: AI influences both elimination of traditional capabilities and creation of innovative human-machine synergies.

independent_variables: Human capabilities (Elo ratings from chess games)
Machine capabilities (Elo ratings of chess engines)
dependent_variables: Chess performance outcomes: Win, Loss, Draw

moderators.name: Human-Machine Interaction Effects
moderators.description: The interaction dynamics in centaur games where humans use AI assistance.

moderators.name: Engine Tuning and Strategic Inputs
moderators.description: Human decisions on engine configurations and database usage influencing outcomes.

sample_and_data_sources.sample: 112 players from 39 federations, participating in 3,281 chess tournaments.

substitution_dynamics: AI substitutes traditional cognitive capabilities, making human Elo ratings less predictive.
In engine chess, AI fully replaces human decision-making capabilities.
complementation_dynamics: Human-machine collaboration in centaur chess creates new competitive advantages.
Human creativity and contextual understanding complement AIâ€™s tactical precision.
quantitative_insights: Human-AI collaboration leads to increased win probabilities in centaur games.
AI-driven substitution reduces performance heterogeneity in engine games.
strategic_implications: Organizations should nurture skills complementing AI capabilities, like creativity and strategic decision-making.
AI adoption shifts competitive advantage from traditional capabilities to human-machine synergies.

criticism: Findings are limited to chess, which may not generalize to real-world strategic contexts.
High-level AI integration assumed in the study may not reflect current industry realities.
future_research_directions: Apply findings to dynamic industries like healthcare and finance.
Explore human 'augmentation skills' to complement AI-driven strategies.
